turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: That's impossible.

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: It's a miracle.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Mrs. Argon?  It's Sim.

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: Mr. Sim?  Do you have him?  He's alive?

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Oh yeah, he's alive.  Technically.

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: And you have him?

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: We lost him.

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: Vermin...

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Can I help you, Mrs. Argon?

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: I spoke to Dr. Argon this morning and he remains frustrated over the loss of the original nanobot.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I am aware of Dr. Argon's frustrations.

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: He believes that the second nanobot should be ready for testing by now.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Under the circumstances, I can't fathom what makes Dr. Argon think we are ready for anything bigger.  If C.N.N., or hell, if the E.P.A. knew what was in my basement --

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: Is that a threat, Dr. Bright?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Look, as I have said and will continue to say, the instability of the assembler waste remains my priority --

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: While you remain on the staff at Argon Laboratories, your priorities will always be the same as Dr. Argon's priorities.  I imagine that is a simple enough equation for a bright girl like you to figure out.

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: If you don't have any questions, I'll let you get back to doing your job.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Just one question.  Since Dr. Argon no longer has feeling below his waist, how is it that you're still able to do your job?

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: I could have you fired right now.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You won't.  That's why you're whispering.

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: Icky!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Get him, Daniel!  Knock his block off!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Okay, Barbie, let's get this over with.

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: Don't worry, four eyes.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It might be paranoia, but I've never lost my keycard before.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: 'Paranoia is what separates the secured from the unsecured.'

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: If this nutcase did take it and has half a brain, he'd use it right away, before we could invalidate it.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes, that is what I was thinking.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: In fact, would it be safe to say, based on your general knowledge of this character, that he is already in the building?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes, he might be.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What in the hell?

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Pipe down, brain lady!  And you...

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, Stew and I went for a long ride.  Dexter, is there any finishing school we can send him to?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Yes - Sing Sing.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Yes, it'll be a very interesting experiment.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: To make a gentleman out of a tramp?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Now, Anne, you remember how much it cost to get rid of that baseball player?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You don't seem to understand that this one's different. He has brains.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Well, what else do you expect them to call you?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Dexter.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Indeed? How interesting.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Yes - isn't it.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Miss Wilson will give you the guest list and any other details you may need, Miss Gallagher.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Thank you. I'll go and look for her at once. Goodbye, Mrs. Smith.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Goodbye, Miss Gallagher.

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: Goodbye, Stew

turns.speaker: GALLAGHER
turns.text: I think I better go, Stew.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I think you should, Miss Gallagher.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Don't mind Mother.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I don't mind her if you don't.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I'm sure you're quite willing to be decent about this.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Decent? Why Miss Schuyler, I want to be noble.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You're not going to print this silly thing, are you?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: No? Why not?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You know something, lady, if you sold life insurance, I'd go for a policy in sixty seconds.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, thank you, I knew you'd understand.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: May I use your telephone?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Certainly. Right over there.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You're all right.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: That's a good idea - telephone the police. The number is Spring 3100. Get a couple of cops over and we can have a rubber of bridge.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You may go, Smythe.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, I tell you, yesterday when I was here, I had one of your books in my hand, and when I got outside, I realized I still had your book in my hand. So as long as I had your book in my hand, I thought I might as well take it home and read it. This morning, I got up and put your book in my hand, and here's your book in your hand.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: That's considerate of you.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yeah, that was considerate of me. I recommend you read it.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I'm not interested in your literary recommendations.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, maybe it's a bit heavy for you. Perhaps if you'd like something lighter - something with a touch of romance

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Just listen to this  Adorable Babykins Does her miss her Baby? Him sends his booful li'l sweetums a billion oceans full of kisses. Bobo is so lonely!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Just a moment. I don't see how that trash could possibly concern me.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Ah!  But you don't know who Bobo is. And you don't know who Babykins is.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I'm not interested. Smythe will open the door.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Where did you get those letters?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I stole them when I was interviewing Babykins about Bobo.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I suppose you're going to print them?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: No - give you another guess.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, I don't need another guess. It's quite obvious.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: So, it's obvious, huh?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Will you step into the library?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure, I'll take a chance.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Will - uh - five thousand be enough?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: For the letters, of course.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I don't know how to thank you. Mother'll be so grateful - she'll probably want to kiss you.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Your mother will want to kiss me? Give me back my letters.  That's the breaks I get. It's the mothers that are always grateful to me.  Here.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You're a peculiar person. Why the other day I pleaded with you not to send in that story and 

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I know but that was news. This is blackmail and I don't like blackmail.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: won't even pretend it isn't a very great favor. I wish there was something I could do for you

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, you could make this table a little - uh - a little less wide.  There is something you can do for me, Miss Schuyler.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yeah, I haven't figured out the plot yet, but it's laid in a Siberian village.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You're a bit eccentric, aren't you?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Me? No - most ordinary guy in the world, me. Only one thing wrong with me

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You don't wear garters!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I'm just beginning to believe that something could be done with you.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Say, you could do anything with me you wanted to. Putty - just putty, that's me.  Now getting back to those eyes of yours - would you mind if I kind of got closer so I could see them?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Not if you're going to lose any sleep about it.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, Mother!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: It's all right. It's all right, Anne. I can take a hint. A bit subtle, but I get it. It's all right.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Please go. I'll explain to Mother.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Hello, Natalie. Mr. Stewart Smith . . . Miss Montgomery, Mrs. Eames, Mrs. Radcliff, Mr. Radcliff

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: How-di-do.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Why should I? We're happy, aren't we, darling?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Throw me out - because I'm beginning to get goofy ideas, and they concern you, Anne.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: None of your ideas can be goofy, Stew, if they concern me.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: My name is Smith - well, that you seem to have been able to stand for the last month. I'm white, male and over twenty-one. I've never been in jail - that is, not often. And I prefer Scotch to Bourbon. I hate carrots, I hate peas, I like black coffee and I hate garters. I make seventy-five bucks a week and I've got eight hundred and forty-seven bucks in the bank - and - I don't know yet whether your eyes are blue or violet.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: That's because you're too far away, Stew.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Now Mother, your attitude is perfectly ridiculous. It's done now. Stewart and I are married.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'm afraid she's right, Mrs. Schuyler. I'm really very sorry, Mrs. Schuyler, that you feel this way. I was in hopes that you would like me. I'm not the burglar that you think I am. After all, we're married. I think the thing to do is to kiss and make up - Mother.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: A little? Sure, I'll be right up.  He's all right. I like him.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I'm glad.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: What's the matter? Something I et, no doubt. Egg marks the spot

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You ought to get some new ties, Stewart.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I don't need any new ties. I've got another tie - I've got another one besides this one. And it's a pip, too. There's only one thing wrong with it. You know what that is?  It has a little weakness for gravy, and once in a while it leans a little toward ketchup. Of course that's only in its weaker moments. When you move down to my place, I'll show it to you.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Your place?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yeah. Oh, it's great. Of course it doesn't compare with this coliseum of yours here, but 'twill serve m'lady, 'twill serve.  The architecture has a little feeling of Missouri Gothic - and the furniture sort of leans toward Oklahoma Renaissance - with a tiny touch of Grand Rapids.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Don't you think it's silly of us to think of living there when we have this whole big house

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: When 'we' . . .?  You mean, you'd like to have me live here in your house?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: We could have the whole left wing? Wouldn't that be nice! Would that be room enough for us?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh darling, of course it would. If it isn't - there are six rooms and two baths - but if that isn't enough, Mother will give us the blue room too, I think.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh, Mother will give us the blue room. You haven't a red room, have you?  Well, bless her heart. Wouldn't that be nice! My, oh my - six rooms and two baths and a blue room. I guess she would let us have the right wing if we needed it, wouldn't she?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: But we don't need it, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I see, we won't need that. Plenty of room, plenty of room.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Look Anne, you're not serious about this, are you?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Of course I am Stewart.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now let's get this settled

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You have the cutest nose I've

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Never mind my nose. What kind of a chump do you think I am? You think I'm going to live here in your house - on your dough?  What do you think my friends would all say? Don't be silly. I'd get the razzing of my life for that. 'A bird in a gilded cage' - that's what I'd be. Not me. Oh no, not me!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: What do you think my friends would say if they found me in a little cheap flat?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: It isn't cheap. It's nice.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Listen Stew baby, let's not talk about things like that now

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Wait a minute. I'll do anything you ask me, Anne, but I will not live

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, I love that nose. It's such a sweet nose.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I've got a present. Shut your eyes. Keep 'em closed. I know you're going to love them.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Little - couldn't be an automobile, could it?  Well, well! Ain't that nice!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Do you like them?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Got my initials on them too. They're cute. They're nice little things - what do you do with them?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You wear them of course, silly.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh no. No, no. Not me. I haven't worn these things for Years.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I know that.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Besides I'd look foolish. I couldn't look Gallagher in the face.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Darling, I don't care whether you can look Gallagher in the face or not, but you're gonna be a good boy and wear garters.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Honey, I love you. I'll eat spinach for you. I'll go to the dentist twice a year for you. I'll wash behind my ears for you. But I will never wear garters!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, yes you will my dear - oh, yes you will my dear - you'll wear garters and you'll like it too!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh, no I won't my dear - oh, no I won't my dear - I'll wash behind my ears, but no I won't my dear!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, yes you will my dear - oh, yes you will my dear - you'll eat spinach but you'll wear garters too!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh, you can't carry a tune - you can't carry a tune - all you are good for is to sit and spoon, spoon. Oh no, I won't wear garters

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh yes you will wear garters

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Anne, prepare yourself for the treat of your life. This is Gallagher.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Gallagher!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure - my pal on the paper. She's subbing for the society editor tonight.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, yes, of course. How do you do?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Gallagher, this is Mrs. Smith.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You know, Stewart, you failed to mention that Miss Gallagher was a very beautiful young girl.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Gallagher?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Yes. As a matter of fact, you failed to mention that Gallagher was a girl.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Didn't I? That's funny. Isn't it funny?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Yes - isn't it?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: No? What do you look upon her as?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Why, down at the office, we always look at Gallagher as - eh - just Gallagher, that's all.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: That was kind of a rotten thing to do, Anne. After all, Gallagher is my friend. The least you can do is be courteous to her.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I thought I was very charming, Stewart.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You did? That's a lot of hooey! I'll go and apologize.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Is this true, Stewart? Did you really say it?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yes, I said it. Sure, I said it. I didn't say it for publication, however.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Stewart! We're all waiting for you. Where's your valet?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I poisoned him.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Stop trying to be funny, and get ready, will you?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'm not going!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'm talking about - I'm not going out.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: What am I going downstairs and tell those people?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Go downstairs, and tell them - anything. Tell them I'm not going. Tell them I'm not home.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Stewart, would you mind telling me why you're not going?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yes, I'll tell you - for the same reason I've never wanted to go out with those social parasites, those sweet-smelling fashion plates. I don't like them. They bore me. They give me the jitters.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Anne, come here. Listen

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Look out for my lipstick, Stewart.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'll tell you what. Let's you and me sneak out all by ourselves

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Are you crazy?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Think of the fun we can have - we'll sneak down the back stairs and get in the valet's Ford. How's that?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Will you stop being silly, Stewart?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'll tell you what let's do - I'll take you and introduce you to all my gang. Would you like that?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: But I don't want to meet your gang.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I don't mean the newspaper fellows that you don't like. Another gang I know - you'd love them. They're writers and musicians and artists - a great crowd of people - people who do great things. People who are worthwhile.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Meaning, my friends aren't worthwhile, I suppose?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh, they're all right, Anne. But I

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: That's exactly what you mean. Heaven knows you've made that clear to me often enough. Well, I'm sick and tired of it. I've given you party after party - I've taken you to some of the best houses in this town - and introduced you to people of importance - and are you grateful? No! You insult them and act like a bore. I'm sick and tired of having to make excuses for you and the things that you've done. Perhaps it's just as well you're not coming tonight. Maybe I can enjoy myself for once without having to worry about you, and what you're going to do.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh hello, Anne He types furiously.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Good morning. What does this mean?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Oh, that mob downstairs. I guess I got so interested in the play I forgot all about them.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Have we got a play, Anne? Oh, have we got a play!  Of course most of it is Gallagher's. She did most of it. That brain of hers just snaps like that all the time.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: What's the idea, Anne?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: The idea is simply this - that I want those people to leave here immediately.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now wait a minute. Aren't you being a little unreasonable?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Unreasonable!  Have you any idea what the place looks like downstairs? Do you expect me to stand here and see this place turned into a cheap barroom?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now wait, don't get excited, Anne. There's no reason for that. Perhaps the boys have had a little too much to drink. That's all right. I'm sorry. I'll go right down and throw them out. That's no reason for you to take this attitude. After all, I certainly have a right to invite a few of my friends to my house, haven't I?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Your house?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: O-o-oh, I get you  All right. All right. I don't blame you. I kinda forgot myself for a moment, there. That's what I call getting me told, isn't it, Anne?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: and if it's all the same to you, I'm moving out.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Stewart!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: This is something I should have done a long time ago, only I didn't have sense enough to do it. No, I had to stick around here to try and make a success of something that I knew darn well was a failure from the very beginning. But no more. No more! So that's that.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You can't walk out of here like this.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You've done nothing but watch me - watch me! - ever since I've been here. Treated me like a thug, watched me like a hawk, mistrusted me. Every time I leave the house, that Jane  goes out and counts the silverware.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: That's ridiculous.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Fine!  I don't blame her. I know I'm out of my own crowd. I should have had better sense in the beginning. But I'll stay in my own backyard from now on.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You're acting like a child.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: All right, I'm a child. Have it any way you want. But I'm going back to my own apartment, where I should have lived in the first place. But no, I got to listen to you and move here. All right. If you want to live with me, Anne, okay. But the sign outside will say "Mr. Stew Smith" and you'll have to be "Mrs. Stew Smith" or there's nothing doing. No more Anne Schuyler's husbandHe has his bag all packed by this time. He snaps it shut viciously, lifts it off the chair, picks up his hat, and notices Mrs. Schuyler staring open-mouthed at him.  and here's some more news for you. You can take your red room, your green room, your left wing and your right wing, and you know what you can do with them!  Come on, Gallagher.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You should have known better than to write, Romeo. I found that out a long time ago.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: I should say you had. At the rate you two are going, we'll have to leave the country to save our faces.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Splendid, Mother. Let's hop over to Monte Carlo. It's a great place to save a face.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Oh, shut up!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: That's an excellent idea.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, hello Mother!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: What is this person doing here?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Why

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: It's a good thing your father passed away before he saw insanity ravage the family. I can't imagine what made you do such a thing. A reporter! Of all things, a reporter! A barbarian who lets his socks come down!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Mother, I promise you that he won't be a reporter much longer. Once I get him away from that atmosphere and get him away from a man named Gallagher

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Sit down!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Good morning, Mother. Didn't I tell you that he'd be marvelous. Everybody thought he was so charming last night.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: I was so worried for fear he'd knock over a vase or something. I must have acted like an idiot.  What does it say about the reception last night?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh, the usual thing. Blah, blah, blah attended the blah, blah reception and wore the same blah, blah things.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Stop it. Anne. You're behaving like the person you're married to.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You don't have anything to complain about, Mother. He was all right last night, wasn't he? I told you not to worry about him.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: It was a miracle. The man was ill or something.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Ah-ah-ah!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Mother!

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: Look! Look! The front page!

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Why doesn't Dexter show some decency? And you might show some too, Mother. What do you expect a man to do when he's called such names?  I'm glad you hit that reporter, Stewart. He deserved it.

turns.speaker: MRS. SCHUYLER
turns.text: All right, all right! It's your funeral, Anne Schuyler!

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Hello, there, Meadows![13]

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Who is it you wish to see, sir?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: I want to see Stew Smith. Oh excuse me - I mean Mr. Smith.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: Pardon me, Mr. Smith is engaged. We are having a reception here this evening

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Oh, a party! Great, great! Jolly times and merry pranks. That's me. I'm a guy who loves parties. You know

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: a beautiful pair of shoulders! But listen now, as a favor, will you please make it snappy, Laughing Waters,[14] and tell Stew Smith I gotta see him because if you don't my whole family's going to die.

turns.speaker: SMYTHE
turns.text: I'll tell Mr. Smith at once, sir. Have a seat.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Well, I got a seat, but I have no place to put it.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: What's the matter? Isn't there a 'bless you' in the crowd?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: You're the Tribune man?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Yeah, hello. How are you?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Fine. Have a seat.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Thanks, I will.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: This way.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Oh, man!

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Fine newspaper the Tribune.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Well, I should say!

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: I knew your managing editor very well.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Is that so?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Yale '21, I believe.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: We were classmates.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: I got him his job on the paper. I'm a stock-holder, you know.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Is that so?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: As one Tribune man to another

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Yeah!

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: But right now I'm acting in the capacity of Mrs. Schuyler's attorney.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Oh, that's all right with me. I won't hold it against you. But you see, I'm here to find out about

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: I know, I know. But there's no truth in the story whatsoever.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Oh yeah?

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: So, you see how silly that rumor is?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Why, sure. It's a lotta hooey.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: That's what I wanted to say, but I couldn't think of it.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: All right, all right, don't mention it.

turns.speaker: GRAYSON
turns.text: Give my regards to your managing editor.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: I certainly will.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Say, take it easy! Take it easy! Listen, my boy. No use you hanging around here. Just buy the Tribune tonight and read all about it. You can rewrite it for your last edition.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Couldn't make the last edition. It'd take me four hours to translate your story into English.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Oh, is that so?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Impossible. Put it on again.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Hey, make up your mind, will you?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Oh, nothing. I just blew over - I wanted to see how the old newshound looked made up for a gentleman.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Would you like to have me turn around for you, Bingy?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Oh boy, I'd love it.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: How's that?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Not bad - not good - but not bad. You ought to be able to fool about almost anybody.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Is that so? Well, have you seen enough - or would you like a photograph?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: A photograph? What's the matter? Hasn't mama had you done in oils yet?  "Just A Gigolo . . . "

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now get this mug. You've got the kind of chin I just love to touch. And if you don't get out of here, I'm going to hang one right on it.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: I bring a message from Garcia.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Yeah. The boss sent me over to offer you a job. He wants you to write a daily column on the Tribune.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yeah - go on.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: It's all right. You can write your own ticket. A hundred and fifty bucks a week.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I'll bite. What's the catch?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: There's no catch. This is on the up and up. Of course all you have to do is just sign the article - by Anne Schuyler's Husband.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Is there a green elephant standing beside that bwana?

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: No, it's just little Bingy Baker.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Big Chief Bingy come to white man's tepee to make friends. Big Chief very sorry. To show how sorry - will bend over and let white man kick Big Chief where sun never shines.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Excuse me, Gallagher. I wouldn't miss this one for the world.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: Well, Stew, that's all thrashed out. By golly, I'm surely glad to see that you're not really sore. You know our racket - after all, news is news.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Sure, sure. That's all right. That was a great story, Bingy. A great story - wish I'd printed it.

turns.speaker: BINGY
turns.text: I gave you the breaks, didn't I? That hairy chest story!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You've raised it up to the chin, I see.  Go on in the other room and get yourself a drink.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Look, I quit!

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: You're always picking on me. It took me three hours to get those little gadgets in those holes, and you screw it up in a minute. Hey, look!

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Aagh! No wonder you're batty. Would it be imposing too much upon you if I asked you to do a little work today? Just to sort of break the monotony?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: With me you can always do business.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Do you know what to do in a drawing- room?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: It isn't a question of knowing what to do, it's knowing how to get in one that counts.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Now listen, we've got a tip that the Schuyler family has finally made a deal with that chorus dame.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Gloria Golden?

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Yeah, little Gloria.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: The human cash register. Got her hooks into the Schuyler kid, eh?

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Right - for the first time this year.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well - it's only April.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Come on, get going, get going!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Get going where? I can write that yarn without stepping out of the office.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Yeah - and get us into a million dollar libel suit. It wouldn't be the first time. Now, you get over there and get a statement out of the old lady, the sister, or the kid. Any of them - but get it.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: All right. Give me a voucher for expenses.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: What expenses? All you need is carfare to Long Island. You'd better get a shave and a shine, because you, you're going to have a tough time getting in there as it is.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: I know those bluenoses. Their ancestors refused to come over on the Mayflower because they didn't want to rub elbows with the tourists. So they swam over.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now listen boss, if you're going to kick about that expense account

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Do you call yourself a reporter?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: It has been alleged - yes

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: You wouldn't know news if you fell into a mess of it, nose first. So you're the bright lad that's never been scooped!

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Not on my own beat, no.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: No? Well, where were you when that happened?

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: I've heard of people being scooped on their own funerals, but this! Holy mackerel! Why, it's news when Anne Schuyler gets her fingernails manicured, but this! She gets married to one of our own reporters and the Tribune beat us to it!  Well! What do you guys want? Go on, get back to your desks. Go back to your work.  Now don't tell me you were drunk at the time and don't remember! Or is this one of Bingy's snow-storms?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: No, no - it's true, all right, only we didn't want to get it in print yet, that's all.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Well, you see, I've acquired one of those new mother-in-laws, and we were afraid she wouldn't understand the whole idea. So we were going to wait till she went to Europe.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: What do I care about your mother- in-law! You're still working for this paper, aren't you! Or are you?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Well, it's your business to get news! And here you had a story right in your own lap and you let the Tribune scoop us on it. Making a first class Grade A monkey out of me. If it ever happens again - just don't bother about coming back. That's all.

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Gallagher and myself just came over here to do a little work on a story -

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Baloney!  Joe! Bring me a special!

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Well, when are you quitting?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Quitting? I'm not thinking about quitting.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Mr. Schuyler .

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: Now get this, Conroy. My name is Smith. Always was Smith - and always gonna be Smith.

turns.speaker: CONROY
turns.text: Is that so?

turns.speaker: STEW
turns.text: That's so.
